Money Wage Inflexibility and the Keynesian Labour Supply Function
Money Supply Control: Reserves as the Instrument Under Lagged Accounting

Money Multiplier As a Determinant of Money Supply: The Case of
      Pakistan
items.abstract:
<jats:p>Monetary policy is an important instrument for pursuing growth
      and stability in a less developed economy. However, it can yield desired
      results if and only if it is judiciously formulated and properly
      implemented. An appropriate formulation of monetary policy requires two
      basic relations to hold: (1) the demand function for money must be
      reasonably stable and empiri¬cally available to the monetary authorities
      and (2) the stock of money must be subject to control by the monetary
      authorities and the mechanism through which money supply is
      quantitatively determined in an economy should be clear to the
      policy-makers.</jats:p>

Polyelectrolyte Persistence in a Municipal Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>Laboratory investigation revealed that a particular polyelectrolyte added to raw water as a coagulant and filter aid was present in the finished water; the polyelectrolyte in the finished water appeared as the polymer and as monomers; and the polyelectrolyte or other added chemicals reacted with the organic compounds in raw water forming new substances that were transferred through the various stages of water treatment to the finished water prior to discharge to the distribution system.</jats:p>

title: PRESENT TECHNOLOGIES OF SOLAR HEATING, COOLING AND HOT WATER SUPPLY IN JAPAN
Application of an Interindustry Supply Model to Energy Issues
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> An interindustry model relating gross output to the availability of primary inputs is used to examine supply linkages associated with national energy production. The results of calculations for US data highlight the importance of extractive energy sectors in intermediate production, and identify supplying sectors that have the potential of restricting energy output. The use of this model as a means to simulate the impact of alternative energy-allocation programmes on gross output is discussed and the results of one simulation are presented. </jats:p>

title: Achievements in Water Supply Treatment and Technology in South America
items.abstract: <jats:p>Latin America has made great advancements in the potable water field. Relinquishing traditional designing procedures, South Americans are pioneering the application of modern technology on a large scale. Rapid mix, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, upflow filters, and double filtration are covered.</jats:p>

title: Agriculture in the Postbellum South: The Economics of Production and Supply
World supply and demand situation for oilseeds, oils, and meals
container-title: Journal of the American Oil Chemists' Society
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In recent years, the demand for meal has been relatively stronger than for vegetable oils. Thus, we have to get the meal demand if we want to determine the extent of oil production and the requirements of oilseeds. This is true although the average annual increase in world meal consumption has declined from 5.5% during the five seasons ended 1970–71 to probably 3.8% in the following five seasons. The share of soybean meal is predominating and ever increasing from 49% ten years ago to as much as 61% this season.</jats:p><jats:p>In most seasons, including the current one, soybean oil output is determined by the more rapidly increasing meal demand. It is thus often in surplus supply, specifically at present. The marketing of soybean oil is becoming even more difficult as world supplies of low‐cost palm oil and lauric oils are increasing more and more sharply.</jats:p><jats:p>World supplies of oilseeds are developing in cycles of ca. seven years—three years buildup stocks and four years liquidation. The present expansion period, which ends this season, has been more pronounced owing to last season's severe economic recession which also affected the consumption of meals and oils/fats.</jats:p><jats:p>Present prospects for the next five seasons point to a slowing‐down of the increase in world production of soybeans, soybean oil, and meal owing to a continuing sharp expansion of supplies of palm oil and lauric oils. This assumes that the general economic activity will more or less stagnate or show only a small expansion during this period.</jats:p>

title: Abundance of food supply and size of the bank vole's home range

The American Revolution II Were building now...to avoid now to avoid a supply crisis later
THE DEMAND‐SUPPLY THEORY OF INCOMES TESTED BY 1970 CENSUS FIGURES
Nitrate Reductase and Nitrite Reductase Activity in Dark‐Grown Radish Seedlings: Relation to the Supply of NADPH
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Functioning of nitrate reductase and nitrite reductase was measured in intact cotyledons from radish seedlings (<jats:italic>Raphanus sativus</jats:italic> L.) grown in the dark in a nitrate medium. Reduction of nitrate to nitrate did proceed during the whole period of 45 h, whereas the reduction of nitrite in the intact cotyledons dropped abruptly between 20 and 23 h after exposing the roots to nitrate.</jats:p><jats:p>The activity of the enzymes glucose‐6‐P dehydrogenase (G6PDH) and 6‐P‐gluconate dehydrogenase (6PGDH), measured in cotyledon extracts, showed a sharp decline simultaneously with the drop in nitrite reductase activity of the intact cotyledons. It was concluded that the amount of NADPH generated by the enzymes G6PDH and 6PGDH is not sufficient to allow continuous functioning of nitrite reductase after 20 h in cotyledons of seedlings grown in the dark. Therefore, the results from our experiments point to the functioning of nitrite reductase as the rate limiting step in the reduction pathway of nitrate in the dark.</jats:p>
